<h1 id="cognite-api-transformation-schedules">Transformation Schedules</h1>

Transformation schedules allow you to run transformations with a specific input at intervals defined by a cron expression. These transformation jobs will be asynchronous and show up in the transformation job list. Visit http://www.cronmaker.com to generate a cron expression with a UI.

<a id="opIdgetTransformationSchedules"></a>

## createTransformationSchedules

<a id="opIdcreateTransformationSchedules"></a>

> Code samples

```python
from cognite.client.data_classes import TransformationSchedule
schedules = [TransformationSchedule(id = 1, interval = "0 * * * *"), TransformationSchedule(external_id="transformation2", interval = "5 * * * *"))]
res = client.transformations.schedules.create(schedules)

```

```java
List<Transformation.Schedule> objects = new ArrayList<>(); 
objects.add(Transformation.Schedule.newBuilder()  
          .setExternalId("10")  
          .setInterval("*/5 * * * *")  
          .setIsPaused(false)  
          .build());
List<Transformation.Schedule> createdListSchedules =
```

## createTransformationNotifications

<a id="opIdcreateTransformationNotifications"></a>

> Code samples

```python
from cognite.client.data_classes import TransformationNotification
notifications = [TransformationNotification(transformation_id = 1, destination="my@email.com"), TransformationNotification(transformation_external_id="transformation2", destination="other@email.com"))]
res = client.transformations.notifications.create(notifications)

```

```java
List<Transformation.Notification.Subscription> subscribes =  
          List.of(Transformation.Notification.Subscription.newBuilder()  
          .setDestination("test@test.com")  
          .setTransformationId(10)  
          .build());
List<Transformation.Notification> createdSubscribes =  
          client.transformations().notifications().subscribe(subscribes);

```

<h1 id="cognite-api-annotations">Annotations</h1>

Annotations reflect contextual information in base CDF resource types, such as Files and Time series, that are not
present on the object itself. The benefits of the annotations concept are threefold:

- The annotations concept is a good fit for enriching the base resources themselves, so that the overall data
  quality is higher in a given project.
- It is also a good fit for building reference datasets for data problems uniformly across customer projects.
  Product teams can then use those reference datasets to train machine learning models or validate the
  performance of their algorithms on actual customer data.
- Given a uniform way of labelling similar concepts across projects, it becomes easy for apps to agree on a consistent
  visual representation of those concepts.

`POST /api/v1/projects/{project}/annotations`

*Create annotations*

Creates the given annotations.

### Identifiers
An annotation _must_ reference an **annotated resource**.

The reference can be made by providing the internal ID of the annotated resource.

### Status
The annotation _must_ have the `status` field set to either "suggested", "rejected", or "approved"

### Access control
The caller _must_ have read-access on all the **annotated resources**, otherwise the call will fail.

### Annotation types and Data
The annotation **type** property _must_ be set to one of the globally available annotation types.
See the documentation of the `annotationType` and `data` attributes for details.

The annotation **data** _must_ conform to the schema provided by the annotation type.

### Creating Application and User
The creating application and its version _must_ be provided. The creating user _must_ be provided, but if the
annotation is being created by a service, this _can_ be set to `null`.

> Body parameter

```json
{
  "items": [
    {
      "annotatedResourceType": "file",
      "annotatedResourceId": 1337,
      "annotationType": "images.ObjectDetection",
      "creatingApp": "cognite-vision",
      "creatingAppVersion": "1.2.1",
      "creatingUser": "john.doe@cognite.com",
      "data": {

        },

}
```

#### Detailed descriptions

**»»» creatingUser**: A username, or email, or name. This is not checked nor enforced. If the value is null, it means the
annotation was created by a service.

**»»» data**: The annotation information. The format of this object is decided by and validated against the `annotationType`
attribute.

**»»»» *anonymous***: Models an image object detection represented by a label, a geometry, and
optionally a confidence value.

**»»»»» polygon**: A _closed_ polygon represented by _n_ vertices. In other words, we assume
that the first and last vertex are connected.

**»»»» *anonymous***: Models an image classification represented by a label, and optionally a
confidence value.

**»»»» *anonymous***: Models a collection of keypoints represented by a label, a dictionary of
keypoints (mapping from a (unique) label name to a keypoint), and
optionally a confidence value and an attributes dictionary.

**»»»»»» primitives.geometry2d.Keypoint**: A point attached with additional information such as a confidence value and
various attribute(s).

**»»»»»»» box**: A box in 3D space, defined by a 4x4 row-major homogeneous transformation matrix that rotates and
translates a unit box centered at the origin to it's location and orientation in 3D space.

**»»»» *anonymous***: Represents a detection of a field value in a form.
A field is identified by a field_name, optionally component_name and component_type if the field belongs to a subcomponent.
The bounding_box indicates the position of the detection. The content of the field is given by the value, and optionally
an unnormalized_value and the unit.

`POST /api/v1/projects/{project}/annotations/suggest`

*Suggest annotations*

Suggests the given annotations, i.e. creates them with `status` set to "suggested"

### Identifiers
An annotation _must_ reference an **annotated resource**.

The reference can be made by providing the internal ID of the annotated resource.

### Access control
The caller _must_ have read-access on all the **annotated resources**, otherwise the call will fail.

### Annotation types and Data
The annotation **type** property _must_ be set to one of the globally available annotation types.
See the documentation of the `annotationType` and `data` attributes for details.

The annotation **data** _must_ conform to the schema provided by the annotation type.

### Creating Application and User
The creating application and its version _must_ be provided. The creating user _must_ be provided, but if the
annotation is being created by a service, this _can_ be set to `null`.

> Body parameter

```json
{
  "items": [
    {
      "annotatedResourceType": "file",
      "annotatedResourceId": 1337,
      "annotationType": "images.ObjectDetection",
      "creatingApp": "cognite-vision",
      "creatingAppVersion": "1.2.1",
      "creatingUser": "john.doe@cognite.com",
      "data": {
        "assetRef": {
          "externalId": "abc"
        },
        "symbolRegion": {
          "xMin": 0.1,
          "xMax": 0.2,
          "yMin": 0.1,
          "yMax": 0.2
        },
        "textRegion": {
          "xMin": 0.2,
          "xMax": 0.3,
          "yMin": 0.2,
          "yMax": 0.3
        },
        "pageNumber": 43
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

#### Detailed descriptions

**»» creatingUser**: A username, or email, or name. This is not checked nor enforced. If the value is null, it means the
annotation was created by a service.

**»» data**: The annotation information. The format of this object is decided by and validated against the `annotationType`
attribute.

**»»» *anonymous***: Models an image object detection represented by a label, a geometry, and
optionally a confidence value.

**»»»» polygon**: A _closed_ polygon represented by _n_ vertices. In other words, we assume
that the first and last vertex are connected.

**»»» *anonymous***: Models an image classification represented by a label, and optionally a
confidence value.

**»»» *anonymous***: Models a collection of keypoints represented by a label, a dictionary of
keypoints (mapping from a (unique) label name to a keypoint), and
optionally a confidence value and an attributes dictionary.

**»»»»» primitives.geometry2d.Keypoint**: A point attached with additional information such as a confidence value and
various attribute(s).

**»»»»»» box**: A box in 3D space, defined by a 4x4 row-major homogeneous transformation matrix that rotates and
translates a unit box centered at the origin to it's location and orientation in 3D space.

**»»» *anonymous***: Represents a detection of a field value in a form.
A field is identified by a field_name, optionally component_name and component_type if the field belongs to a subcomponent.
The bounding_box indicates the position of the detection. The content of the field is given by the value, and optionally
an unnormalized_value and the unit.

`POST /api/v1/projects/{project}/annotations/list`

*Filter annotations*

Lists the annotations the caller has access to, based on a filter.

The caller _must_ have read-access on the **annotated resources** listed in the filter, otherwise the call will
fail.

> Body parameter

```json
{
  "cursor": "MzE1NjAwMDcxNzQ0ODI5",
  "limit": 25,
  "filter": {
    "annotatedResourceType": "file",
    "annotatedResourceIds": [
      {
        "id": 1066
      },
      {
        "id": 1067
      }
    ],
    "status": "approved",
    "data": {
      "label": "cat"
    }
  }
}
```

<h3 id="annotationsfilter-parameters">Parameters</h3>

|Name|In|Type|Required|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|project|path|string|true|The project name.|
|body|body|object|true|A request specifying the annotation listing behavior|
|» cursor|body|[StrCursor](#schemastrcursor)¦null|false|A cursor pointing to another page of results|
|» limit|body|integer|false|none|
|» filter|body|[AnnotationsV2FilterSchema](#schemaannotationsv2filterschema)|true|A filter to apply on annotations|
|»» annotatedResourceType|body|[AnnotatedResourceType](#schemaannotatedresourcetype)|true|The annotated CDF resource. Files as well as 3d-Models are supported.|
|»» annotatedResourceIds|body|[[ResourceReference](#schemaresourcereference)]|true|[A reference to another CDF resource. _Either_ the internal _or_ the external ID _must_ be provided (not both).]|
|»»» id|body|[CogniteInternalId](#schemacogniteinternalid)(int64)|false|A server-generated ID for the object.|
|»»» externalId|body|[CogniteExternalId](#schemacogniteexternalid)|false|The external ID provided by the client. Must be unique for the resource type.|
|»» annotationType|body|[AnnotationType](#schemaannotationtype)|false|The type of the annotation. This uniquely decides what the structure of the `data` block will be.|
|»» creatingApp|body|[Application](#schemaapplication)|false|The application name or identifier. This is neither checked nor enforced.|
|»» creatingAppVersion|body|[SemanticVersion](#schemasemanticversion)|false|A version number in the SemVer sense. See [semver.org](https://semver.org/) for the specification.|
|»» creatingUser|body|[User](#schemauser)¦null|false|A username, or email, or name. This is not checked nor enforced. If the value is null, it means the|
|»» status|body|[Status](#schemastatus)|false|The status of the annotation|
|»» data|body|object|false|Filter annotations by their data keys and values (case-sensitive). Concretely, by providing this field, we check for all annotations that contains the data filter as a subset.|

#### Detailed descriptions

**»» creatingUser**: A username, or email, or name. This is not checked nor enforced. If the value is null, it means the
annotation was created by a service.

**»» data**: Filter annotations by their data keys and values (case-sensitive). Concretely, by providing this field, we check for all annotations that contains the data filter as a subset.
If `annotationType` is not specified, the data filter will applied across all annotation types.

#### Enumerated Values

|Parameter|Value|
|---|---|
|»» annotatedResourceType|file|
|»» annotatedResourceType|threedmodel|
|»» annotationType|images.ObjectDetection|
|»» annotationType|images.Classification|
|»» annotationType|images.KeypointCollection|
|»» annotationType|images.AssetLink|
|»» annotationType|images.TextRegion|
|»» annotationType|diagrams.AssetLink|
|»» annotationType|diagrams.FileLink|
|»» annotationType|diagrams.UnhandledTextObject|
|»» annotationType|diagrams.UnhandledSymbolObject|
|»» annotationType|documents.ExtractedText|
|»» annotationType|diagrams.Line|
|»» annotationType|diagrams.Junction|
|»» annotationType|pointcloud.BoundingVolume|
|»» annotationType|forms.Detection|
|»» status|suggested|
|»» status|approved|
|»» status|rejected|

#### Detailed descriptions

**»» update**: Each fields represent a "delta" that will be applied onto the corresponding field of the original
annotation.

### Updating Annotation Type or Data
Ensure that the new annotation data conforms to the new annotation type, otherwise the call will fail.

**»»»» set**: The annotation information. The format of this object is decided by and validated against the `annotationType`
attribute.

**»»»»» *anonymous***: Models an image object detection represented by a label, a geometry, and
optionally a confidence value.

**»»»»»» polygon**: A _closed_ polygon represented by _n_ vertices. In other words, we assume
that the first and last vertex are connected.

**»»»»» *anonymous***: Models an image classification represented by a label, and optionally a
confidence value.

**»»»»» *anonymous***: Models a collection of keypoints represented by a label, a dictionary of
keypoints (mapping from a (unique) label name to a keypoint), and
optionally a confidence value and an attributes dictionary.

**»»»»»»» primitives.geometry2d.Keypoint**: A point attached with additional information such as a confidence value and
various attribute(s).

**»»»»»»»» box**: A box in 3D space, defined by a 4x4 row-major homogeneous transformation matrix that rotates and
translates a unit box centered at the origin to it's location and orientation in 3D space.

**»»»»» *anonymous***: Represents a detection of a field value in a form.
A field is identified by a field_name, optionally component_name and component_type if the field belongs to a subcomponent.
The bounding_box indicates the position of the detection. The content of the field is given by the value, and optionally
an unnormalized_value and the unit.

`GET /api/v1/projects/{project}/3d/files/{threedFileId}`

*Retrieve a 3D file*

Retrieve the contents of a 3D file.

This endpoint supported tag-based caching.

This endpoint is only compatible with 3D file IDs from the 3D API, and not compatible with
file IDs from the Files API.

```python

```

```java
Path fileAOriginal = Paths.get("./src/test/resources/csv-data.txt"); 
List<FileContainer> fileContainerInput = new ArrayList<>(); 
FileMetadata fileMetadata = FileMetadata.newBuilder() 
          .setExternalId("10") 
          .setName("test_file_.test") 
          .setSource("sdk-data-generator") 
          .putMetadata("type", "sdk-data-generator") 
     .build(); 

 FileContainer fileContainer = FileContainer.newBuilder() 
          .setFileMetadata(fileMetadata) 
          .setFileBinary(FileBinary.newBuilder() 
               .setBinaryUri(fileAOriginal.toUri().toString())) 
          .build(); 
 fileContainerInput.add(fileContainer); 

 List<FileMetadata> uploadFileResult = 
          client.files().upload(fileContainerInput); 

ThreeDModelRevision.Camera camera = ThreeDModelRevision.Camera.newBuilder() 
 .addPosition(2.707411050796509).addPosition(-4.514726638793945).addPosition(1.5695604085922241) 
 .addTarget(0.0).addTarget(-0.002374999923631549).addTarget(1.5695604085922241) 
.build(); 
ThreeDModelRevision revision = ThreeDModelRevision.newBuilder() 
 .setFileId(uploadFileResult.get(0).getId()).setCamera(camera).addRotation(new Random().nextInt(100) / 100.0) 
.build(); 
List<ThreeDModelRevision> listUpsert = 
          client.threeD() 
          .models() 
          .revisions() 
          .upsert(10L, List.of(revision)); 

```

`GET /api/v1/projects/{project}/3d/models/{modelId}/revisions/{revisionId}/outputs`

*List available outputs*

Retrieve a list of available outputs for a processed 3D model. An output can be a format that can be consumed by a viewer (e.g. Reveal) or import in external tools. Each of the outputs will have an associated version which is used to identify the version of output format (not the revision of the processed output). Note that the structure of the outputs will vary and is not covered here.

<h3 id="list3dmodeloutputs-parameters">Parameters</h3>

|Name|In|Type|Required|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|project|path|string|true|The project name.|
|modelId|path|integer(int64)|true|Model ID.|
|revisionId|path|integer(int64)|true|Revision ID.|
|format|query|string|false|Format identifier, e.g. 'ept-pointcloud' (point cloud). Well known formats are: |

#### Detailed descriptions

**format**: Format identifier, e.g. 'ept-pointcloud' (point cloud). Well known formats are: 
'ept-pointcloud' (point cloud data) or 'reveal-directory' (output supported by Reveal). 
'all-outputs' can be used to retrieve all outputs for a 3D revision. Note that some of 
the outputs are internal, where the format and availability might change without warning.

> Example responses

> 200 Response

```json
{
  "items": [
    {
      "format": "ept-pointcloud",
      "version": 1,
      "blobId": 1
    }
  ]
}
```

|---|---|---|---|
|200|[OK](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6.3.1)|Returns a list of outputs and available versions per output for the given revision.|[Model3DOutputResponseList](#schemamodel3doutputresponselist)|

`GET /api/v1/projects/{project}/3d/models/{modelId}/revisions/{revisionId}/nodes`

*List 3D nodes*

Retrieves a list of nodes from the hierarchy in the 3D model. You can also request a specific subtree with the 'nodeId' query parameter and limit the depth of the resulting subtree with the 'depth' query parameter. By default, nodes are returned in order of ascending treeIndex. We suggest trying to set the query parameter `sortByNodeId` to `true` to check whether it makes your use case faster. The `partition` parameter can only be used if `sortByNodeId` is set to `true`. This operation supports pagination.

<h3 id="get3dnodes-parameters">Parameters</h3>

|Name|In|Type|Required|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|project|path|string|true|The project name.|
|modelId|path|integer(int64)|true|Model ID.|
|revisionId|path|integer(int64)|true|Revision ID.|
|partition|query|string|false|Splits the data set into N partitions.|
|cursor|query|string|false|Cursor for paging through results.|
|limit|query|integer|false|Limits the number of results to be returned. The maximum results returned by the server is 1000 even if you specify a higher limit.|
|depth|query|integer(int32)|false|Get sub nodes up to this many levels below the specified node. Depth 0 is the root node.|
|nodeId|query|integer(int64)|false|ID of a node that are the root of the subtree you request (default is the root node).|
|sortByNodeId|query|boolean|false|Enable sorting by nodeId. When this parameter is `true`, nodes will be listed in order of ascending nodeId. Enabling this option will likely result in faster response for many requests.|
|properties|query|string(jsonObject(jsonObject(string)))|false|Example: `{"category1":{"property1":"value1"}}`|

#### Detailed descriptions

**partition**: Splits the data set into N partitions.
You need to follow the cursors within each partition in order to receive all the data.
Example: 1/10

**properties**: Example: `{"category1":{"property1":"value1"}}`

Filter for node properties. Only nodes that match all the given properties exactly will be listed.
The filter must be a JSON object with the same format as the `properties` field.

> Example responses

> 200 Response

```json
{
  "items": [
    {
      "id": 1000,
      "treeIndex": 3,
      "parentId": 2,
      "depth": 2,
      "name": "Node name",
      "subtreeSize": 4,
      "properties": {
        "category1": {
          "property1": "value1",
          "property2": "value2"
        },
        "category2": {
          "property1": "value1",
          "property2": "value2"
        }
      },
      "boundingBox": {
        "max": [
          0,
          0,
          0
        ],
        "min": [
          0,
          0,
          0
        ]
      }
    }
  ],
  "nextCursor": "string"
}
```

|---|---|---|---|
|200|[OK](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6.3.1)|A list of nodes of a revision.|[Node3DWithCursorResponse](#schemanode3dwithcursorresponse)|
|400|[Bad Request](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6.5.1)|The response for a failed request.|Inline|

<a id="opIdfilter3DNodes"></a>

> Code samples

```python
res = client.three_d.revisions.filter_nodes(model_id=1, revision_id=1, properties={ "PDMS": { "Area": ["AB76", "AB77", "AB78"], "Type": ["PIPE", "BEND", "PIPESUP"] } }, limit=10)

```

```java
//without parameters 
Iterator<List<ThreeDNode>> itFilter = client.threeD() 
          .models() 
          .revisions() 
          .nodes() 
          .filter(model.getId(), revision.getId()); 
 List<ThreeDNode> listResults = itFilter.next(); 

//with parameters 
Request request = Request.create() 
          .withFilterParameter("properties", createFilterPropertiesWithCategories()); 

List<ThreeDNode> listResults = new ArrayList<>(); 
client.threeD() 
          .models() 
          .revisions() 
          .nodes() 
          .filter(model.getId(), revision.getId(), request) 
          .forEachRemaining(val -> listResults.addAll(val)); 

private ThreeDNode.PropertiesFilter createFilterPropertiesWithCategories() { 
     ThreeDNode.PropertiesFilter.Categories.CategoriesValues.Builder catValBuilder = 
          ThreeDNode.PropertiesFilter.Categories.CategoriesValues.newBuilder(); 
     catValBuilder.addValuesString("Box"); 
     ThreeDNode.PropertiesFilter.Categories.Builder catBuilder = 
          ThreeDNode.PropertiesFilter.Categories.newBuilder(); 
     catBuilder.setName("Item"); 
     catBuilder.putValues("Type", catValBuilder.build()); 
     ThreeDNode.PropertiesFilter.Builder propsBuilder = 
          ThreeDNode.PropertiesFilter.newBuilder(); 
     propsBuilder.addCategories(catBuilder.build()); 
     return propsBuilder.build(); 
 } 

```

Detect annotations in engineering diagrams. Note: All users in a CDF project with assets read-all and files read-all capabilities can access data sent to this endpoint.

> Body parameter

```json
  "items": [
    {
      "pageRange": {
        "begin": 51,
        "end": 100
      },
      "fileId": 1234
    }
  ],
  "entities": [
    {
      "userDefinedField": "21PT1017",
      "ignoredField": "AA11"
    },
    {
      "userDefinedField": [
        "21PT1017-A",
        "21PT1017-B"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "searchField": "userDefinedField",
  "partialMatch": false,
  "minTokens": 2
}
```

`POST /api/v1/projects/{project}/context/diagram/convert/`

*Convert a diagram to image format*

Convert interactive engineering diagrams to image format, with highlighted annotations.
Supported input file mime_types are application/pdf, image/jpeg, image/png, image/tiff.
Supported output image formats are PNG and SVG, only the svg embeds the input annotations.

> Body parameter

```json
{
  "items": [
    {
      "fileId": 1234,
      "annotations": [
        {
          "text": "21-PT-1019",
          "confidence": 0.5,
          "region": {
            "shape": "rectangle",
            "vertices": [
              {
                "x": 0.58,
                "y": 0.12
              },
              {
                "x": 0.58,
                "y": 0.12
              },
              {
                "x": 0.58,
                "y": 0.12
              },
              {
                "x": 0.58,
                "y": 0.12
              }
            ],
            "page": 1
          },
          "entities": [
            {
              "userDefinedField": "21PT1017",
              "ignoredField": "AA11"
            },
            {
              "userDefinedField": [
                "21PT1017-A",
                "21PT1017-B"
              ]
            }
          ]
        }
      ]
    }
  ],
  "grayscale": true
}
```

<h3 id="diagramconvert-parameters">Parameters</h3>

|Name|In|Type|Required|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|project|path|string|true|The project name.|
|body|body|object|false|none|
|» *anonymous*|body|object|false|none|
|»» items|body|[allOf]|false|An array of files and annotations to create interactive diagrams.|
|»»» *anonymous*|body|[OneOfFileId](#schemaoneoffileid)|false|An object containing file (external) id. The file can have at most 50 pages.|
|»»»» *anonymous*|body|object|false|none|
|»»»»» fileId|body|[DiagramFileId](#schemadiagramfileid)(int64)|false|The ID of a file in CDF. The file must have mime_type application/pdf, image/jpeg, image/png or image/tiff.|
|»»»» *anonymous*|body|object|false|none|
|»»»»» fileExternalId|body|[DiagramFileExternalId](#schemadiagramfileexternalid)|false|The external ID of a file in CDF. The file must have mime_type application/pdf, image/jpeg, image/png or image/tiff.|
|»»» *anonymous*|body|object|false|none|
|»»»» annotations|body|[allOf]|false|Annotations to draw on the engineering diagrams|
|»»»»» *anonymous*|body|[NewAnnotation](#schemanewannotation)|false|none|
|»»»»»» text|body|string|true|The text and entities detected by the service.|
|»»»»»» confidence|body|number|false|The confidence for the detection.|
|»»»»»» region|body|object|true|none|
|»»»»»»» *anonymous*|body|[DiagramRegion](#schemadiagramregion)|false|Shape and coordinates of the detected entity in the image.|
|»»»»»»»» shape|body|string|true|The geometrical shape of the image region to which a detected entity belongs.|
|»»»»»»»» vertices|body|[[Vertex](#schemavertex)]|true|List of vertices representing the image region to which a detected entity belongs.|
|»»»»»»»»» x|body|number|true|Normalized x coordinate.|
|»»»»»»»»» y|body|number|true|Normalized y coordinate.|
|»»»»»»» *anonymous*|body|object|false|none|
|»»»»»»»» page|body|[Page](#schemapage)|false|The page of the file where the annotations in `annotations` were detected.|
|»»»»» *anonymous*|body|object|false|none|
|»»»»»» entities|body|[object]|false|A list of entities detected per annotation.|
|» *anonymous*|body|[DiagramConvertConfig](#schemadiagramconvertconfig)|false|none|
|»» grayscale|body|[Grayscale](#schemagrayscale)|false|Return the SVG version in grayscale colors only (reduces the file size).|

List of one or more linear rings representing a shape.

A linear ring is the boundary of a surface or the boundary of a hole in a surface. It is defined as a list consisting of 4 or more Points, where the first and last Point is equivalent.

Each Point is defined as an array of 2 numbers, representing coordinates of a point in 2D space.

Example: `[[[35, 10], [45, 45], [15, 40], [10, 20], [35, 10]], [[20, 30], [35, 35], [30, 20], [20, 30]]]`

It is defined as a list consisting of 4 or more Points, where the first and last Point is equivalent.<br><br>Each Point is defined as an array of 2 numbers, representing coordinates of a point in 2D space.<br><br>Example: `[[[35, 10], [45, 45], [15, 40], [10, 20], [35, 10]], [[20, 30], [35, 35], [30, 20], [20, 30]]]`|

<h2 id="tocS_TimestampOrStringStart">TimestampOrStringStart</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schematimestamporstringstart"></a>
<a id="schema_TimestampOrStringStart"></a>
<a id="tocStimestamporstringstart"></a>
<a id="tocstimestamporstringstart"></a>

```json
0

```

Get datapoints starting from, and including, this time. The format is N[timeunit]-ago where
timeunit is w,d,h,m,s. Example: '2d-ago' gets datapoints that are up to 2 days
old. You can also specify time in milliseconds since epoch. Note that for aggregates, the start time is rounded down to a whole granularity unit (in UTC timezone). Daily granularities (d)
are rounded to 0:00 AM; hourly granularities (h) to the start of the hour, etc.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|*anonymous*|integer|false|none|none|

xor

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|*anonymous*|string|false|none|none|

<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schematimestamporstringend"></a>
<a id="schema_TimestampOrStringEnd"></a>
<a id="tocStimestamporstringend"></a>
<a id="tocstimestamporstringend"></a>

```json
0

```

Get datapoints up to, but excluding, this point in time. Same format as for start. Note that when using aggregates, the end will be rounded up such that the last aggregate represents a full aggregation interval containing the original end, where the interval is the granularity unit times the granularity multiplier. For granularity 2d, the aggregation interval is 2 days, if end was originally 3 days after the start, it will be rounded to 4 days after the start.

|---|---|---|---|---|

Whitespace-separated terms to search for in assets. Does a best-effort fuzzy search in relevant fields (currently name and description) for variations of any of the search terms, and orders results by relevance. Uses a different search algorithm than the name and description parameters, and will generally give much better results. Matching and ordering is not guaranteed to be stable over time, and the fields being searched may be extended.|

Sort by array of selected fields. Syntax: `["<fieldname>:asc|desc"]`. Default sort order is `asc` with short syntax: `["<fieldname>"]`.
Filter accepts the following field names:
  `externalId`,
  `type`,
  `subtype`,
  `startTime`,
  `endTime`,
  `createdTime`,
  `lastUpdatedTime`,
  `source`,
  `description`,
  `metadata`.
Partitions are done independently of sorting, there is no guarantee on sort order between elements from different partitions.

### Properties

*None*

Event is considered active from its startTime to endTime inclusive. If startTime is null, event is never active. If endTime is null, event is active from startTime onwards. activeAtTime filter will match all events that are active at some point from min to max, from min, or to max, depending on which of min and max parameters are specified.

The file ID to a file uploaded to Cognite's Files API. This file must be a zip file and contain a file called `handler.py` in the root folder (unless otherwise specified in the `functionPath` argument). This file must contain a function named `handle` with any of the following arguments: `data`, `client`, `secrets` and `function_call_info`, which are passed into the function. The zip file can contain other files as well (model binary data, libraries etc).

Custom packages can be pip installed by providing a requirements.txt file in the root of the zip file. The latest version of the Cognite Python SDK is automatically installed. If a specific version is needed, please specify this in the requirements.txt file.

*None*

```json
      ]
```
```json
    }
  }

```

Filters used in the search.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|properties|object|false|none|Contains one or more categories (namespaces), each of which contains one or more properties. Each property is associated with a list of values. The list of values acts as an OR-clause, so that if a node's corresponding property value equals ANY of the strings in the list, it satisfies the condition for that property. The different properties are concatenated with AND-operations, so that a node must satisfy the condition for ALL properties from all categories to be part of the returned set. The allowed number of property values is limited to 1000 values in total.|

```json
{
```

```json
  "start": 0,
  "end": 0,
  "limit": 100
}

```

Synthetic query description

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|expression|string|true|none|query definition. For limits, see the [guide to synthetic time series](/dev/concepts/resource_types/synthetic_timeseries.html#limits).|
|start|[TimestampOrStringStart](#schematimestamporstringstart)|false|none|Get datapoints starting from, and including, this time. The format is N[timeunit]-ago where<br>timeunit is w,d,h,m,s. Example: '2d-ago' gets datapoints that are up to 2 days<br>old. You can also specify time in milliseconds since epoch. Note that for aggregates, the start time is rounded down to a whole granularity unit (in UTC timezone). Daily granularities (d)<br>are rounded to 0:00 AM; hourly granularities (h) to the start of the hour, etc.|
|end|[TimestampOrStringEnd](#schematimestamporstringend)|false|none|Get datapoints up to, but excluding, this point in time. Same format as for start. Note that when using aggregates, the end will be rounded up such that the last aggregate represents a full aggregation interval containing the original end, where the interval is the granularity unit times the granularity multiplier. For granularity 2d, the aggregation interval is 2 days, if end was originally 3 days after the start, it will be rounded to 4 days after the start.|
|limit|integer(int32)|false|none|Return up to this number of datapoints|

### Properties

|audience|string|true|none|The expected audience value (for CDF)|

|scopeClaims|[ClaimNamesArray](#schemaclaimnamesarray)|true|none|Which claims to use when scoping access granted by access claims|
|logClaims|[ClaimNamesArray](#schemaclaimnamesarray)|true|none|Which token claims to record in the audit log|
|isGroupCallbackEnabled|[GroupCallbackEnabled](#schemagroupcallbackenabled)|false|none|A group callback occurs when a user has too many groups attached. This property indicates whether<br>the group callback functionality should be supported for this project. This is only supported for AAD hosted IdPs.|
|identityProviderScope|string|false|none|The scope sent to the identity provider when a session is created. The default value is the value required for a default Azure AD IdP configuration.|

only users whose username ends with `@` followed by a valid domain in the list
can log in to the project.

**Warning:** If the project is configured with a public identity provider, such as Google,
and this field is left empty, then *any* user with an account, even outside your organization,
may log in to the project.

Filter on relationships with exact match. Multiple filter elements in one property, for example `sourceExternalIds: [ "a", "b" ], returns all relationships where the sourceExternalId field is either `a` or `b`. Filters in multiple properties return relationships that match all criteria. If the filter is not specified, it defaults to an empty filter.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|sourceExternalIds|[[resourceExternalId](#schemaresourceexternalid)]|false|none|Include relationships that have any of these values in their `sourceExternalId` field|
|sourceTypes|[[resourceType](#schemaresourcetype)]|false|none|Include relationships that have any of these values in their `sourceType` field|
|targetExternalIds|[[resourceExternalId](#schemaresourceexternalid)]|false|none|Include relationships that have any of these values in their `targetExternalId` field|
|targetTypes|[[resourceType](#schemaresourcetype)]|false|none|Include relationships that have any of these values in their `targetType` field|
|dataSetIds|[[DataSetIdEither](#schemadatasetideither)]|false|none|none|
|startTime|[EpochTimestampRange](#schemaepochtimestamprange)|false|none|Range between two timestamps (inclusive).|
|endTime|[EpochTimestampRange](#schemaepochtimestamprange)|false|none|Range between two timestamps (inclusive).|
|confidence|[floatRange](#schemafloatrange)|false|none|Range to filter the field for (inclusive).|
|lastUpdatedTime|[EpochTimestampRange](#schemaepochtimestamprange)|false|none|Range between two timestamps (inclusive).|
|createdTime|[EpochTimestampRange](#schemaepochtimestamprange)|false|none|Range between two timestamps (inclusive).|
|activeAtTime|[EpochTimestampRange](#schemaepochtimestamprange)|false|none|Limits results to those active within the specified time range, that is, if there is any overlap in the intervals [`activeAtTime.min`, `activeAtTime.max`] and [`startTime`, `endTime`], where both intervals are inclusive. If a relationship does not have a `startTime`, it is regarded as active from the beginning of time by this filter. If it does not have an `endTime` is is regarded as active until the end of time. Similarly, if a `min` is not supplied to the filter, the `min` is implicitly set to the beginning of time. If a `max` is not supplied, the `max` is implicitly set to the end of time.|
|labels|[LabelFilter](#schemalabelfilter)|false|none|Return only the resource matching the specified label constraints.|
|sourcesOrTargets|[[resourceReferenceWithExternalId](#schemaresourcereferencewithexternalid)]|false|none|Include relationships that match any of the resources in either their source- or target-related fields.|


Property you wish to filter. It's a list of strings to allow specifying nested properties.
For example, If you have the object `{"foo": {"../bar": "baz"}, "bar": 123}`, you can refer to the nested property as `["foo", "../bar"]` and the un-nested one as `["bar"]`.

### Properties

*None*

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|geometryFormat|string|false|none|Desired format for geometry output. If GEOJSON is the output format, SRID 4326 must be specified explicitly for all geometrical properties. Defaults to WKT.|

All properties will be returned when the selection is empty or contains the wildcard `*` character. |Property|Value|
|---|---|
|geometryFormat|WKT|
|geometryFormat|GEOJSON|

<h2 id="tocS_GeospatialAllowCrsTransformation">GeospatialAllowCrsTransformation</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemageospatialallowcrstransformation"></a>
<a id="schema_GeospatialAllowCrsTransformation"></a>
<a id="tocSgeospatialallowcrstransformation"></a>
<a id="tocsgeospatialallowcrstransformation"></a>

```json
true

```

Optional parameter indicating if input geometry properties should be transformed into the respective Coordinate Reference Systems defined in the feature type specification. If the parameter is true, then input geometries will be transformed when the input and output Coordinate Reference Systems differ. When it is false, then requests with geometries in Coordinate Reference System different from the ones defined in the feature type will result in bad request response code. Transformations apply to property geometries in case of create and update feature, as well as to geometries in spatial filters in search endpoints.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|*anonymous*|boolean|false|none|Optional parameter indicating if input geometry properties should be transformed into the respective Coordinate Reference Systems defined in the feature type specification. If the parameter is true, then input geometries will be transformed when the input and output Coordinate Reference Systems differ. When it is false, then requests with geometries in Coordinate Reference System different from the ones defined in the feature type will result in bad request response code. Transformations apply to property geometries in case of create and update feature, as well as to geometries in spatial filters in search endpoints.|

```json
true

```

Optional parameter indicating if the spatial filter operators allow input geometries with a different dimensionality than the properties they are applied to. For instance, when set to true, if a feature type has a property of type POLYGONZM (4D), its features can be filtered using the `stContains` operator and a POLYGON (2D) value. This option defaults to false if not specified.

Metrics like `assets.read` mean how many items were fetched from CDF;`assets.create` and `assets.update` inform how many resources were created or updated (note that we count objects as updated even when no field is changed). `requests` says how many HTTP request were made to CDF to complete the job. `requestWithoutRetries` does not count retried requests. Normally, these two metrics should be almost equal, if there is a big difference, it may indicate a problem with rate-limiting.|

<h2 id="tocS_AnnotationsV2UpdateDataSchema">AnnotationsV2UpdateDataSchema</h2>
<!-- backwards compatibility -->
<a id="schemaannotationsv2updatedataschema"></a>
<a id="schema_AnnotationsV2UpdateDataSchema"></a>
<a id="tocSannotationsv2updatedataschema"></a>
<a id="tocsannotationsv2updatedataschema"></a>

```json
{
  "data": {
    "set": {
      "assetRef": {
        "externalId": "abc"
      },
      "symbolRegion": {
        "xMin": 0.1,
        "xMax": 0.2,
        "yMin": 0.1,
        "yMax": 0.2
      },
      "textRegion": {
        "xMin": 0.4,
        "xMax": 0.5,
        "yMin": 0.4,
        "yMax": 0.5
      },
      "pageNumber": 43
    }
  }
}

```

Each fields represent a "delta" that will be applied onto the corresponding field of the original
annotation.

### Updating Annotation Type or Data
Ensure that the new annotation data conforms to the new annotation type, otherwise the call will fail.

### Properties

|Name|Type|Required|Restrictions|Description|
|---|---|---|---|---|
|annotationType|object|false|none|none|
|» set|[AnnotationType](#schemaannotationtype)|true|none|The type of the annotation. This uniquely decides what the structure of the `data` block will be.|
|data|object|false|none|none|
|» set|[AnnotationData](#schemaannotationdata)|true|none|The annotation information. The format of this object is decided by and validated against the `annotationType`<br>attribute.|
|status|object|false|none|none|
|» set|[Status](#schemastatus)|true|none|The status of the annotation|
